A highly efficient Fe/Beta catalyst for the liquid-phase oxidation of naphthalene: The influence of Fe species and zeolite acidity Lei Chen Conceptualization Methodology Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a b Xiaomin Zhang Conceptualization Supervision Project administration a ⁎ Siyu Zhang Writing – review & editing a b Lanjian Xu Writing – review & editing a b Yangyang Yuan Supervision Formal analysis a Lei Xu Conceptualization Supervision Project administration a ⁎ a National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, PR China National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 PR China aNational Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, People's Republic ofR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, People's Republic ofR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Fe/Beta catalysts with various Fe species and acidity were prepared by impregnation (im), ion-exchange (ex) and hydrothermal (hy) method. The properties as well as their catalytic activities were compared by various physicochemical techniques and liquid-phase oxidation of naphthalene (NAP) in detail. Among the three Fe/Beta catalysts, as high as 78% content of isolated Fe3+ species were incorporated into Beta zeolites by hydrothermal method. The isolated Fe3+ species of Fe/Beta(100)-hy distributed homogeneously through the Beta zeolites while the Fe species of Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex distributed preferred on the surface of Beta zeolites. The total acid density increased after the incorporation of Fe species by hydrothermal method. Fe/Beta(100)-hy with the highest content of isolated Fe3+ species and enhanced acid density showed the highest catalytic activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Liquid-phase oxidation of naphthalene Fe/Beta catalyst Isolated Fe3+ species Total acid density 1 Introduction Polyaromatic hydrocarbon (PAHs), which are produced from incomplete combustion of various coal, petroleum, wood, tobacco and other organic macromolecular compounds, are serious environmental and food pollutants. The world health organization (WHO) has classified them as carcinogenic [1]. Naphthalene (NAP) is the simplest molecule of the PAHs, and thus it is commonly studied as a model compound. Furthermore, NAP is also the most volatile component in PAHs, and high concentration of NAP can result in laryngeal tumors and cataracts among contacts [2]. Therefore, it is of great significance to eliminate NAP and the best way was converting NAP into other harmless and high added-value substances. For decades, NAP could be converted through biodegradation [3], ozone oxidation [4], adsorption [5] and catalytic oxidation [6]. Among this, catalytic oxidation of NAP has been proved to be an effective method for both economic and environmental benefits. However, carbon dioxide is the final product in most of the gas-phase catalytic oxidation of NAP reaction. It not only causes wastage of resources but also aggravates the greenhouse effect. In contrast, the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP with H2O2 is an environmentally friendly as well as resource efficient route. During the process, NAP is converted into high added-value products, such as 1,4-naphthoquinone, phthalic anhydride, carboxybenzaldehyde and so on, while H2O is the major by-product. Over the past several decades, developing high-efficiency catalysts has always been a focus of the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. The commonly used catalysts were mainly metal-based catalysts, such as Fe, V, Zr and so on. For example, Shylesh et al. [7] reported the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP over V containing mesoporous molecular sieves catalysts. The conversion of NAP was only 16.0% after reaction for 24 h. Similarly, Wu et al. [8] reported that the conversion of NAP was 26% in the presence of V-TiO2 catalysts which were synthesized by hydrothermal method. In another research, Andas et al. [9] investigated the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP over Fe supported silica catalysts, giving the highest NAP conversion of 48.2%. Due to the high catalytic activity, stability and much low cost, Fe-based catalysts were regarded as one of the most important developed catalysts for the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP among the reported catalysts [10]. Fe-based catalysts were found to have excellent catalytic activity in many liquid-phase oxidation reactions [11–14]. Nonetheless, it is still difficult to distinguish the active Fe sites in given process. This is largely because of the coexistence of multiple types of Fe species, for instance, isolated Fe3+ species, small FexOy clusters as well as large Fe2O3 particles [15]. Different types of Fe species exhibited totally different catalytic activities in the specific process. For instance, Romero-Sáez et al. [16] confirmed that the distribution of Fe nanoparticles deposited on the ZSM-5 affected the catalytic activity to trichloroethylene. In another research, Yuan et al. [17] prepared Fe/MS catalysts and tested their catalytic performances for ammonia decomposition. They found that the physicochemical properties such as Fe distribution, metal-support interaction and metal reducibility influenced their catalytic performance. Recently, researchers have found that different type of Fe species could be constructed by choosing different preparation methods. Hence, it is desirable to choose proper preparation method to construct specific Fe species [7,18,19]. Furthermore, it is of great importance to investigate the influence of Fe species involved in Fe-based catalyst on their activity. In the present study, a battery of Fe/Beta catalysts were obtained by different methods, namely impregnation, ion-exchange and hydrothermal method. Beta zeolite was elected as the support for Fe-based catalysts due to its large micro-pore size (about 0.66 × 0.77 nm in the [100] and [010] dimensions) and strong acidity. The properties of prepared Fe/Beta catalysts were characterized by various techniques, such as XRD, SEM, N2 adsorption-desorption experiments, ICP, UV–vis, NH3-TPD, Py-IR, XPS and FT-IR, etc. The catalytic performance of Fe/Beta catalysts was studied in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP with H2O2 as oxidant. Here we found that the presence of large amount of isolated Fe3+ species as well as the enhanced acid density were key to improve the catalytic activity of Fe/Beta catalyst in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Beta zeolites were synthesized as follows: aluminum sulfate octadecahydrate (Al(SO4)3•18H2O; 98 wt.%) was dissolved in the tetraethylammonium hydroxide solution (TEAOH; 25 wt.%). Thereafter, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS; 98 wt.%) was added into the aforesaid solution and followed with intensely stirring for 6 h at room temperature. Then, hydrofluoric acid (HF; 40 wt.%) was added and homogenized by vigorous stirring. The gel was dried at 353 K and the final molar ratios were SiO2: (0.001–0.01)Al2O3: 0.5TEAOH: 0.75HF: 5H2O. Finally, the gel was transferred to a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and kept at 413 K for 5 days. Then the solid was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 383 K overnight, and calcined at 823 K for 4 h to remove the template. The Si/Al molar ratio of prepared Beta zeolite was 50–500 and the samples were denoted as Beta(50), Beta(100), Beta(300) and Beta(500), respectively. Beta(Si) was prepared by the same method except that aluminum salts were not added to the sol-gel. Three series of Fe-incorporated Beta (Fe/Beta) catalysts were prepared by impregnation (im), ion-exchange (ex) and hydrothermal method (hy). Fe/Beta(x)-im (x represented 50, 100, 300, 500, Si, respectively) catalysts were prepared as follows: 5.0 g of Beta(x) samples were mixed with iron nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3•9H2O; 98 wt.%) solution. Then the mixture was kept at 298 K for 24 h. Afterward the mixture was dried at 383 K and followed by calcined at 823 K for 4 h. The obtained samples were denoted as Fe/Beta(x)-im. Fe/Beta(100)-ex catalysts were prepared as follows: 5.0 g of Beta(100) samples were stirred together with 50 mL of 0.05 mol/L Fe(NO3)3•9H2O solution at 353 K for 2 h. After the ion-exchange procedure, the mixture was centrifuged, washed and dried at 383 K, and finally calcined at 823 K for 4 h. The ion-exchange procedure was repeated 3 times to get the final products. The catalysts were denoted as Fe/Beta(100)-ex. Fe/Beta(100)-hy and Fe/Beta(500)-hy catalysts were prepared via the hydrothermal method which was described above. The molar composition of the gel was SiO2: 0.005/0.001Al2O3: 0.005Fe2O3: 0.5TEAOH: 0.75HF: 5H2O. The catalysts were denoted as Fe/Beta(100)-hy and Fe/Beta(500)-hy with Si/Al molar ratio of 100 and 500 respectively. Fe/Beta(Si)-hy catalysts with similar Fe content of Fe/Beta(100)-hy were prepared by the same method except that aluminum salts were not added to the sol-gel. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns were collected on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. A JSM-7800F scanning electron microscopy was used to image the particle sizes and morphology of catalysts. Textural properties were determined by adsorption of nitrogen and Micromeritics ASAP 2020 was used as apparatus. The specific surface areas were derived from the isotherms and evaluated using the BET equation. The pore volumes were adsorbed at P/P0 = 0.99. The Si/Al molar ratio of the samples was measured using XRF (Philips Magix-601). The Fe content of the dissolved catalysts was obtained by ICP-OES (Optima8000 spectrometer). UV–vis spectra were determined on a Shimizu UV-3600 spectrophotometer. The XPS spectra were performed using a Thermofisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Ka X-ray source (15 kV, 150 W) and analyzer pass energy of 100 eV. The binding energy of C 1 s peak was used as the reference. The FT-IR spectra were monitored by a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer using KBr pellet method. The NH3-TPD spectra of the catalysts were obtained on a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 apparatus. The Py-FTIR spectra were obtained on a Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrometer. The quantitative values of the acid sites were calculated from the integral area values of the difference spectra at ca. 1540 and ca. 1450 cm−1. 2.3 Liquid-phase oxidation of NAP Liquid-phase oxidation of NAP was evaluated in a 50 mL single necked round bottom flask with a reflux condenser and a magnetic stirrer. Typically, 0.24 g catalyst and 0.32 g (2.50 mmol) NAP were added into the reactor and then 10 mL acetonitrile was added. The reaction media was heated to 333 K, and then 1.5 mL (14.69 mmol) 30 wt.% H2O2 was added. After reaction for several hours, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature. The oxidized products were qualitatively identified by GC–MS and quantitatively analyzed by GC. The conversion of NAP was obtained by the internal standard method with 1,3,5-trimethyl benzene as an internal standard. The oxidation product distribution was calculated by area normalization method. The hot filtrate test was carried out as follows: First of all, the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP was carried out for 0.5 h, and then the catalysts were separated by filtration. The residual solution was further stirred for several hours under the same reaction conditions. The recyclability of Fe/Beta was examined as follows: at the end of each reaction circle, the catalysts were separated from the reaction mixture and washed for 3 times, dried at 383 K for 12 h and calcined at 823 K for 4 h, and then tested in the repeated cycle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Firstly, the crystalline structures of the parent Beta(100) and three kinds of Fe/Beta(100) samples prepared via different methods were characterized by XRD (Fig. 1 A). The XRD patterns of Beta(100) and Fe/Beta(100) samples exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks of BEA zeolite. It indicated that the introduction of iron did not cause significant changes of Beta zeolite. Besides, comparing these patterns with α-Fe2O3 peaks, no diffraction peaks were corresponding to iron oxides. The FT-IR spectra of the parent Beta and Fe/Beta(100) samples were displayed in Fig. 2 . It could be seen that all samples displayed the featured IR bands near 525 cm−1, 574 cm−1 and 610 cm−1, which were caused by the stretching vibrations of the double four-membered rings, double five-membered rings and double six-membered rings of the BEA structure, respectively [20,21]. It showed that the introduction of iron did not cause significant changes in the BEA structure, which is consistent with the XRD results. The SEM images of Fe/Beta catalysts were shown in Fig. 3 . As were shown, all samples showed a well-defined crystal. The particle surface was rough and with a nanocrystal-assembled morphology. The particle size distribution of Fe/Beta catalysts was in the range of 1–7 μm. Compared with Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex, the particle size distribution of Fe/Beta(100)-hy was relatively homogeneous. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S1) were measured and gave the textural properties of different catalysts. It was clear shown that all samples displayed a hysteresis loop in the P/P0 range of 0.4–0.99, which presented a typical type IV isotherm, indicating the existence of mesoporous. Combined with the SEM results, it could be speculated that the mesopores were rooted in the void space of adjacent nano-crystallites, which was consistent with the literature report [22]. The detail textural properties were shown in Table 1 . Compared to the parent Beta(100), the BET surface areas for Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex decreased slightly. The decrease of BET surface areas was might be caused by the load of Fe species on Beta zeolite surface. Meanwhile, the surface areas of Fe/Beta(100)-hy were almost the same as Beta(100) zeolites, while the mesoporous volumes and external surface areas were smaller than the others. It indicated that the void space of adjacent nano-crystallites in Fe/Beta(100)-hy was small, resulting in lower mesoporous volumes and external surface areas. The actual Si/Al molar ratios and Fe content were listed in Table 2 . It indicated that the Si/Al molar ratios of Fe/Beta samples were similar. The ICP results showed that the overall bulk Fe loading was about 1.0 wt.% for three Fe/Beta catalysts. XPS is a surface-sensitive analysis method. Therefore, by comparing the results of ICP and XPS, the distribution of Fe on the surface of Beta zeolites could be analysed. As shown in Table 2, the content of Fe species for Fe/Beta(100)-hy was about 1.03 wt.% determined by XPS, which was quite closed to the bulk Fe loading measured from ICP. It indicated the homogeneous distribution of Fe species throughout Beta zeolites. However, the content of Fe exposed on the surface determined by XPS was much higher than the content of bulk Fe measured from ICP for Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex samples, suggesting most of Fe species distributed on the surface of Beta zeolites. XRD was used firstly to evaluate the states of Fe species. It has been reported that the change in the position of (302) diffraction peak around 2θ of 22.4 was generally considered to be the expansion of the framework due to the metal incorporation into the Beta zeolite framework [23,24]. As observed in Fig. 1B (a, d), the main peak at around 2θ of 22.441 for Beta(100) shifted to 22.408 for Fe/Beta(100)-hy. And the d302 spacing calculated from this peak increased from 3.959 Å to 3.964 Å correspondingly. The expansion of the lattice cell was probably as a result of the introduction of Fe into the Beta zeolite [25]. However, the d302 spacing remained unchanged for Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex suggested that Fe had not incorporated into the Beta zeolite framework. XPS was used to further evaluate the surface composition and the chemical states of Fe species. Fig. 4 A showed the XPS results of Fe 2p spectra for different Fe/Beta samples. From the Fe 2p spectrum, two obvious sets of doublet peaks corresponding to Fe 2p3/2 (711–712.1 eV) and Fe 2p1/2 (724–725 eV) were observed, revealing the existence of Fe3+ originating from Fe2O3 [17]. The peak at about 719.2 eV further proved the existence of Fe3+ originating from Fe2O3 [11]. Furthermore, there was no peak at about 706.8 eV, revealing the absence of Fe0 species [26]. In addition, the binding energy value of Fe 2p3/2 in Fe/Beta(100)-hy (711.7 eV) was much larger than that of pure Fe2O3 (710.6–711.2 eV). It might be thanks to the strong interaction between Fe3+ incorporated with silanol groups to form Si-O-Fe bonds [11]. These results indicated that most of Fe atoms were doped into the silicate framework for Fe/Beta(100)-hy materials, which was consistent with the XRD results. As shown in Fig. 4B, two peaks were observed at around 530.3 and 533.2 eV, revealing the presence of the O2− species at two different environments. The peak at around 530.3 eV has been reported to be assigned to the oxygen associated with the extra-lattice Fe species, while the peak position at 533.2 eV was as expected for Si-O bands [27]. For the Fe/Beta(100)-hy, almost no peak around 530.3 eV was observed, suggesting that most of these Fe species were doped into the silica framework. While the peak at around 530.3 eV was observed in Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex, indicating the effective surface enrichment of the Fe oxide phase. UV–vis spectroscopy was used to obtain the nature of Fe species in Fe/Beta catalysts and the results were shown in Fig. 5 . As was illustrated, Fe/Beta catalysts exhibited strong absorbance in the range of 200–600 nm. For all the samples, the strong absorption bands at about 200–300 nm were assigned to t1 → t2 and t1 → e transitions which were involved as isolated Fe3+ species [28]. The band at 300–400 nm which was related to d-d transitions or oligomerized Fe oxide species presented in small FexOy clusters [16]. The absorption bands at 400–600 nm indicated the presence of Fe2O3 nanoparticles [29]. Two bands at 200–250 nm and 250–300 nm were found in all samples. These bands are usually assigned to the isolated Fe3+ in the framework [FeO4] tetrahedral coordination [11,29] or the octahedral complexes of Fe3+ in the extra-framework [16]. According to the XRD and XPS results, there was no framework Fe species formed when Fe was introduced by the impregnation method and ion-exchange method. Therefore, the isolated Fe3+ species were octahedral complexes of Fe3+ in the extra-framework for Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex samples. However, combined with XRD and XPS results, it can be concluded that Fe/Beta(100)-hy samples had a high content of isolated Fe3+ species (200–300 nm), and it has framework [FeO4] tetrahedral coordination species. After the deconvolution of the UV–vis spectra, the relative amount of different Fe species belong to three corresponding characteristic absorption bands were listed in Table 3 . As shown in Table 3, isolated Fe3+ was the main Fe species for Fe/Beta(100)-hy catalysts and the content of isolated Fe3+ was as high as 78 wt.%. While the contents of isolated Fe3+ for Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex catalysts were about 47 wt.% and 45 wt.% respectively. The content of small FexOy clusters and Fe2O3 nanoparticles were relatively high for both Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex catalysts. The results showed that it was easier to form high dispersion of Fe species via hydrothermal method. NH3-TPD was used to evaluate the acidity of the catalysts. Weak, moderate and strong acid sites can be defined based on the desorption temperature of 393–573, 573–773 and 773–973 K, respectively. The acidic properties were characterized and the corresponding NH3-TPD spectra were shown in Fig. 6 . As were shown, all samples showed a desorption peak at around 450 K, which indicated the present of weak acid sites. The desorption peak at around 610 K indicated the moderate acid sites. A new higher-temperature peak around 773 K appeared due to the introduction of Fe. It could be concluded that introduction of Fe resulted in new acid sites. The acid density determined by NH3-TPD were listed in Table S2. Fe/Beta(100)-hy samples have the highest total acid density. The total acid density increased slightly for Fe/Beta(100)-im and decreased slightly for Fe/Beta(100)-ex. The obvious acidic differences probably derived from the different Fe species as well as their distribution. To gain deeper insight into the acidity of the catalysts, Py-IR spectra were obtained and shown in Fig. 7 . As could be seen from Fig. 7, all catalysts exhibited the bands and 1548, 1490 and ca. 1450 cm−1. The bands at ca. 1450 and 1548 cm−1 are attributed to LAS and BAS, respectively [30]. The band at 1490 cm−1 is ascribed to the superimposed signal of BAS and LAS [31]. The band at 1454 cm−1 for Beta(100) shifted to 1448 cm−1 for Fe/Beta samples, which was caused by the introduction of Fe. The concentrations of LAS and BAS were calculated from the corresponding IR adsorption peak at 423 K and the results were listed in Table 4 . The total acid density measured by pyridine IR is generally lower than that measured by NH3-TPD due to the larger molecule of pyridine than ammonia [32]. As shown in Table 4, the total acid density followed the order of Fe/Beta(100)-hy>Fe/Beta(100)-im>Fe/Beta(100)-ex. These results were consistent with the obtained total acid density from NH3-TPD. In summary, as indicated by the NH3-TPD and Py-IR results, the Fe/Beta(100)-hy samples prepared by hydrothermal method have the highest total acid density. 3.2 Liquid-phase oxidation of NAP The catalytic performance of Fe/Beta catalysts was investigated in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. The oxidation products identified by GC–MS were listed in Table S3. Products obtained in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP were identified as 1,4-naphthoquinone (1,4-NAP), carboxybenzaldehyde (CBD), phthalic anhydride (PAD), 2-Hydroxy-1,4-naphthoquinone (2-HY-1,4-NAP) and some other products. On the basis of the GC–MS results and combined with the literature reports, the possible mechanism for the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP was free radical reaction mechanism [7,9,33]. The selectivity of main products for the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP was plotted as a function of reaction time and the results were shown in Fig. 8 . Three samples displayed similar evolution trends and PAD was the most plentiful product, followed by 1,4-NAP and CBD. The selectivity of PAD exceeded 30% at the beginning of the reaction and increased slowly versus time over all catalysts. Meanwhile, the selectivity of 2-HY-1,4-NAP closed to 20% at the beginning of the reaction, which decreased rapidly and only remained about 10% after reacting for 4 h. The selectivity of 1,4-NAP and CBD increased after reacting for 2 h. As was shown, 1,4-NAP, CBD, PAD and 2-HY-1,4-NAP were the main products and the total selectivity of them was higher than 80% over the three Fe/Beta catalysts. The selectivity of oxidation products did not show obvious changes trend, which indicated that the catalyst property of Fe/Beta had little influence on the distribution of oxidation products of NAP. The concrete effects of catalyst property on their catalytic activity were evaluated in detail as follows. First, blank reaction with no catalyst added and a compared reaction over Beta(100) as catalysts were performed respectively. No NAP was converted illustrating that NAP could not be transformed without Fe-based catalyst in this system. The reaction results of the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP over Fe/Beta(100)-im, Fe/Beta(100)-ex and Fe/Beta(100)-hy catalysts were visualized in Fig. 9 . For all the Fe/Beta catalysts, the conversion of NAP was abrupt at early 2 h of the reaction. The best catalytic activity has been found for Fe/Beta(100)-hy catalyst and the conversion of NAP was 44.2% under current reaction conditions. While less than 35% of NAP was converted in the presence of Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex catalysts. It could be seen that Fe/Beta(100)-hy catalyst gave the highest activity than that of Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex catalysts. The highest activity probably derived from the high isolated Fe3+ species or the high acid density of catalysts. Herein, the Fe species and acid density effects on the activity in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP were investigated respectively. To discussed the influence of Fe species, two comparison samples named Fe/Beta(500)-hy and Fe/Beta(Si)-hy were prepared using hydrothermal method. The XRD results shown in Fig. S2 confirmed that Fe/Beta(500)-hy and Fe/Beta(Si)-hy kept BEA structure and Fe introduced into Beta framework. As shown in Fig. S1 and Table 1, Fe/Beta(500)-hy and Fe/Beta(Si)-hy kept the same structure of other samples. The acidity results of these samples shown in Fig. S4 and Table S2 displayed obviously different. The peak position for Fe/Beta(100)-hy was higher than Fe/Beta(500)-hy and Fe/Beta(Si)-hy samples, which could be caused by the difference in acidic strength between Al(OH)Si and Fe(OH)Si groups [34,35]. The ICP, UV–vis and NH3-TPD results shown in Fig. S3, Table 2, Table 3, Fig. S4 and Table S2 proved that Fe/Beta(500)-hy and Fe/Beta(100)-im had similar Fe contents and similar acid density, but the Fe distributions displayed obviously different. A similar phenomenon existed for Fe/Beta(Si)-hy and Fe/Beta(100)-ex. As shown in Table 5 , the conversion of NAP reached 43.2% for Fe/Beta(500)-hy, which was far higher than Fe/Beta(100)-im (30.2%). Similarly, the conversion of NAP over Fe/Beta(Si)-hy reached 41.7% and was higher than Fe/Beta(100)-ex (34.4%). Hence, it could be drawn a conclusion that the higher activity of Fe/Beta(500)-hy and Fe/Beta(Si)-hy probably derived from their high content of isolated Fe3+ species. As we mentioned above, the introduction of Fe affected the acid density of the Fe/Beta catalyst. And the acid density of zeolites played an important role in many oxidation reactions [36]. Herein, the acid density effect on the activity in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP was investigated. To discuss the influence of acid density, a series of Fe/Beta samples with different Si/Al molar ratios were prepared using impregnation method. The total acid density of the catalysts increased from 17 to 424 μmol/g (NH3-TPD results) when Si/Al molar ratios decreased. Fig. 10 showed the change in the conversion of NAP as a function of the acid density. First, almost no NAP was converted over Fe/Beta(Si)-im catalyst with barely acid sites. It indicated that acid sites of Fe/Beta catalyst were necessary for the conversion of NAP. The conversion of NAP increased from 0.3% to 30.2% when the total acid density of the catalysts increased from 17 to 230 μmol/g, indicating that the conversion of NAP increased along with the increase of acid density for the catalysts. But when the acid density further increased to 424 μmol/g, the conversion of NAP increased further. It could be seen that the conversion of NAP changed in a small range (30.2% to 35.6%) though their acidities exhibited great changes (230 μmol/g to 424 μmol/g). A similar phenomenon existed for Fe/Beta(Si)-hy, Fe/Beta(500)-hy and Fe/Beta(100)-hy. Total acid density of the catalysts increased from 168 to 367 μmol/g (NH3-TPD) when Si/Al molar ratios decreased. The conversion of NAP increased from 41.7% to 44.2% correspondingly. Based on the above results, it could be seen that acid sites of Fe/Beta catalysts were necessary for the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. But when the acid density reached an appropriate concentration, the continuous increase of the acid density could only improve the catalytic activity to some extent. It suggested that the increase in acid density combined the high content of isolated Fe3+ species were responsible for the improvement of the activity in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. From the above analysis, both iron species and catalyst acid density affect the activity of liquid-phase oxidation of NAP, and a free radical reaction mechanism was speculated according to the literature and the GC–MS results. Considering the crucial role of activation of H2O2, we investigated the effect of catalysts on H2O2 activation, and the results were shown in Fig. 11 . It is normally considered that the converted H2O2 involves two parts: one part was to produce HO• and HOO•, and the other part was consumed on account of the self-decomposition [37,38]. In many liquid-phase oxidation reactions with Fe-based catalysts, it is inevitably to cause the decomposition of H2O2. For Fe/Beta(100)-hy catalysts, the conversion of H2O2 increased quickly in the initial 1 h and shown 98.5% conversion after 4 h of the run. However, for the Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex catalysts, the conversion of H2O2 reached maximum of 79.1% and 61.1%, respectively. Fe/Beta(100)-hy with high content of isolated Fe3+ species and enhanced acid density were more capable to activate H2O2 than Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex catalysts. To investigate the effects of acid density and Fe species separately, the H2O2 conversion over comparison materials were investigated. Fig. 11C showed the change in the conversion of H2O2 as a function of the acidity. Firstly, the conversion of H2O2 increased from 14.5% to 79.1% when the total acid density of Fe/Beta(x)-im increased from 17 to 230 μmol/g (NH3-TPD) correspondingly. When the acid density further increased, the speed for the conversion of H2O2 tend to be gentle. The similar phenomenon existed for Fe/Beta(Si)-hy, Fe/Beta(500)-hy and Fe/Beta(100)-hy. Secondly, the conversion of H2O2 over Fe/Beta(100)-ex and Fe/Beta(Si)-hy samples with similar acid density but significantly different distributions of Fe species was 61.6% vs 80.7%, respectively. The increase of activity suggested that the isolated Fe3+ species exhibited higher activity for the activating of H2O2. Based on these results, the presence of abundant isolated Fe3+ species and the enhancement of acid density were responsible for the high conversion of H2O2. It indicated that the iron species and acid density of catalysts could affect the activation of H2O2, and thus influence the catalytic activity of liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. Based on the results of our research and others’ studies [9,36], a possible free radical catalytic reaction mechanism was proposed under the studied condition. Firstly, H2O2 was adsorbed on the Fe/Beta catalysts and activated on the active Fe species to form •OH. After •OH produced, they attacked the substrate NAP, leading to the formation of hydroxycyclohexadienly (HCHD) radical [39]. Subsequently, the formed primary oxidation products of NAP undergoes H-atom abstraction by oxidants. Different primary oxidation products formed due to that α or β positions of NAP were attacked by the •OH. The primary oxidation products of NAP were more reactive than NAP, so the •OH continues to attack the primary oxidation products of NAP, and finally a complex distribution of oxidation products was formed. The stability of Fe/Beta catalysts was examined in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. First of all, metal leaching tests were performed to investigate the stability of Fe species over all the catalysts. As showed in Fig. 9, the enhancement of NAP conversion was detected after resubmission of the filtrate over Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex under the reaction conditions, pointing out that some of Fe species were leached out during the reaction process. The leached iron species with H2O2 formed Fenton-like reagents in the reaction media, which acted as homogeneous catalysts to catalyze the continued conversion of NAP. However, Fe/Beta(100)-hy catalysts showed almost null catalytic activity after the catalysts were filtered out, indicating that almost no Fe species leaching during the catalytic process. It could be concluded that the conversion of NAP over Fe/Beta(100)-hy catalysts is a case of heterogeneous catalysis. The high stability of Fe species of Fe/Beta(100)-hy could be attributed to the strong bind of Fe-O-Si into the framework of Beta zeolites. Thus, the stability of Fe species under the present reaction conditions, could be rationalized in the following order, Fe/Beta(100)-hy>Fe/Beta(100)-im>Fe/Beta(100)-ex. The recyclability of Fe/Beta(100)-hy was also examined in the liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. As showed in Fig. 12 , the catalytic activity could be easily recovered and reused for four times in the NAP conversion. These results demonstrated the high reusability of Fe/Beta(100)-hy due to the high stability of Fe species doping into the silicate framework. High stability was one of the most important properties for practical application in the industry, and Fe/Beta catalysts prepared by hydrothermal method might be the potential catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of NAP. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a series of Fe/Beta catalysts were obtained by three different methods: impregnation, ion-exchange and hydrothermal method. Their properties were characterized by various physicochemical techniques. The highest content of isolated Fe3+ species could be incorporated by hydrothermal method in comparison with impregnation and ion-exchange method. The incorporation of Fe species, especially the isolated framework tetrahedral Fe3+ species, caused the enhancement of acid density. Although the distribution and status of Fe species were different, the oxidation products selectivity did not show any obvious difference. Experimental results verified that iron species and the amount of acid sites influence the catalyst activity. Fe/Beta(100)-hy which was prepared via hydrothermal method exhibited the highest conversion of NAP and H2O2 due to the highest content of isolated Fe3+ species and enhanced acid density. The iron species and acid density of catalysts could affect the activation of H2O2, and thus influence the catalytic activity of liquid-phase oxidation of NAP. Compared to the effect of acid density, high content of isolated Fe3+ species played the dominant role for the enhancement of catalytic activity of Fe/Beta(100)-hy catalysts. All the results illuminated that the Fe/Beta samples prepared by the direct hydrothermal method might be the potential catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of NAP. coredata.dc:description: Fe/Beta catalysts with various Fe species and acidity were prepared by impregnation (im), ion-exchange (ex) and hydrothermal (hy) method. The properties as well as their catalytic activities were compared by various physicochemical techniques and liquid-phase oxidation of naphthalene (NAP) in detail. Among the three Fe/Beta catalysts, as high as 78% content of isolated Fe3+ species were incorporated into Beta zeolites by hydrothermal method. The isolated Fe3+ species of Fe/Beta(100)-hy distributed homogeneously through the Beta zeolites while the Fe species of Fe/Beta(100)-im and Fe/Beta(100)-ex distributed preferred on the surface of Beta zeolites. The total acid density increased after the incorporation of Fe species by hydrothermal method. Fe/Beta(100)-hy with the highest content of isolated Fe3+ species and enhanced acid density showed the highest catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: A highly efficient Fe/Beta catalyst for the liquid-phase oxidation of naphthalene: The influence of Fe species and zeolite acidity
